content.description:
This is a very short off-width with room to do maybe one or two jams before topping out onto your stomach under a roof that juts out over the crack.  You probably don't really have to do any jams if you don't want to.  You could try to pull the roof above the top-out ledge I guess, but didn't look particularly doable and definitely would be sketchy if you tried.

For extra fun, slither on your belly through the gap between the roof and the rock you're on to down-climb around the corner to the right of where you start.

This problem is super short and kind of dumb.
content.protection: A pad.  The route tops out at 8 feet, so you can pretty easily just step off unless you've got a wicked foot jam going on.
content.location: If you're walking along the west side of the rock formation behind the outhouse at Site C in the Practice Rock campground, this is the obvious off-width crack under an overhang.  Hard to miss.

content.description:
This is a short problem requiring serious body tension.

Sit start with your right side-pulling on a decent knob and a left gaston on an okay scoop.  Stand up to another crappy gaston.  Get your right out to an opposing gaston and transition your left across to match the same lip as your right.  Reach wide right for a good hold above the roof.  Continue to traverse right till you can find a good hold to hook, roll, and mantle out the finish.

The crux is getting into the double gaston and then getting your feet up for the transition to the match.
content.protection: A pad. The lip on the roof is only 7 feet off the ground, but a high heel hook is the likely top out technique, so a pad under the top-out would be a good idea on the unlikely chance your hands blow after you've thrown the heel.
content.location: As you walk along the west side of the rock formation behind the outhouse at Site C in the Practice Rock campgound, you'll pass an off-width crack and shortly after walk between a small boulder on your left and an overhanging rock formation on your right.  Walk 15 more feet after that until you see a small tree against the rock wall.  Look for a scoop feature under the roof; that scoop is the double gaston on Hint of Lime.
